title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
YAML
---
title: "Document title"
author: "Lewis Forwarder"
output: html_document
---

Starts with ---, ends with ---
Intuitive syntax \(\rightarrow\) field: value
Outputs: HTML, docx, pptx, (pdf)

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Markdown
Intuitive language to write, in plain text, a document that is transformed into a report (in Rstudio, go to submenu “Help > Markdown Quick Reference” for a quick tour).

Emphasis
*italic*   **bold**
_italic_   __bold__
Headers
# Header 1
## Header 2
### Header 3

Unordered List
* Item 1
* Item 2
    + Item 2a
    + Item 2b

Ordered List
1. Item 1
2. Item 2
3. Item 3
    + Item 3a
    + Item 3b

And so much more!

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
R Chunks
Your code goes in “R chunks”1.



```{r chunk title, echo = TRUE}
hist(rnorm(100))
```











Customization:

Beginners: ⚙️,
Intermediate users: go here,
Advanced users: Yi Hui’s website.


click on “+c” to insert a chunk quickly

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Other features

PDF: \(\LaTeX\)
Maths: \(\LaTeX\)
Customized HTML documents: CSS (ou SCSS)
Diagrams: mermaid or GraphViz
Other high-level programming languages: Python, Julia, SQL
Other: bash, Rcpp (C++), Stan (Bayesian statistics), etc.

title: Reproducible Reports with R Markdown
text:
Most useful fields

title: title of the document
author: your name
output:

html_document \(\rightarrow\) is the easiest to use
word_document \(\rightarrow\) is very convenient
pdf_document \(\rightarrow\) requires \(\LaTeX\)

title: Introduction and Reminders
text:
Schedule, language, etc

Day 1: tips and tricks of dplyr and ggplot2. Create a report in R Markdown.
Day 2: Heatmaps, and other advanced graphical representations. Create panels of plots. Good practices in data visualization.
Day 3: work on your data.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text: In this workshop, you will reproduce Figure 2 from (Ong et al. 2020) (from the cleaned data located here) and write a short report explaining your choices, results, and limitations.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
The Figure
Figure 2 contains three sub-panels:

a clustered heatmap with sample annotations,
longitudinal expression profiles for inflammatory genes,
longitudinal expression profiles for T-cell markers.

title: Workshop: reproduce a complex panelled figure
text:
Detailed instructions
Work in groups of 3–4.
Start with each subfigure individually to break up your workload. For example:

create a project,
save the dataset (located here) in the project’s folder and load it in the environment,
reproduce first the subfigure showing the expression profile of IL1A with ggplot2,
create a function from the previous code that takes as input the name of the gene and outputs the figure,
create subpanels B and C with patchwork,
work on reproducing the heatmap with ComplexHeatmap,
combine everything in one big panel.

Write your comments describing your work in an R Mardown document, with an HTML output, breaking down the steps.
At the end of the day, present your work: what you achieved, where you had difficulties, the questions you had. We will show you our own version.

title: Visualization
text:
Day 2
Aim of the day:

Assess the quality of a scientific plot.

Copy and improve a graph using ggplot2.

Gather plots using patchwork.

make some (Complex)Heatmaps.

annotate with statistics (ggpubr).

automate the graphic generation.

title: Visualization
text:
Visualization
outline

graphics: The good, the bad and the ugly
Personalize
One graphic to gather them all
Adding statistics and automate graphs

title: Visualization
text:
why ?

A graph is a mean of communication, not a goal.

An advanced graph : - Conveys complex information clearly
- Integrates multiple layers of information
- Is reproducible and adaptable by code
- Is aesthetically pleasing and follows conventions

title: Visualization
text:
Practice: Critical Analysis
Assess the following graphs.

Is the main message clear ?
what are the strengths and weakness ?

title: Visualization
text:
Common Bad Practices

Inaccessible colors (problematic for people with color blindness)
Chartjunk: unnecessary decorative elements (busy backgrounds, overly prominent grids)
Non-proportional axes that mislead perception
Information overload: too much data on a single graph
Imprecise or missing legends and labels

title: Visualization
text:
The 10 Commandments of Good Graphs

Rule 1: Know Your Audience
Rule 2: Identify Your Message - 1 main message per graph Rule 3: Adapt the Figure to the Support Medium - paper - conference - 2. Choose the geometry that suits your message
Rule 4: Captions Are Not Optional Rule 5: Do Not Trust the Defaults Rule 6: Use Color Effectively 4. You shall honor color accessibility (viridis)
Rule 7: Do Not Mislead the Reader 3. You shall name your axes and title clearly
Rule 8: Avoid ‘‘Chartjunk’’ 5. Thou shalt remove “chart junk”
Rule 9: Message Trumps Beauty 6. Thou shalt use accurate scales 7. Thou shalt annotate to guide the reader 8. Thou shalt test readability (font size)
Rule 10: Get the Right Tool - R
They also exaplified the 9. Thou shalt ensure reproducibility with your code > Notes All the figures for this article were produced using matplotlib, and figure scripts are available from https://github.com/rougier/ten-rules.

Thou shalt seek external opinion!

title: Visualization
text: load relevant libraries

title: Visualization
section: The viridis Palette: Queen of Accessibility
text:
The viridis Palette: Queen of Accessibility

# simple graphs with different palettes
p1 <- ggplot(faithfuld, aes(waiting, eruptions, fill = density)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "viridis") +
  ggtitle("Viridis") +
  theme_minimal()

p2 <- ggplot(faithfuld, aes(waiting, eruptions, fill = density)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "plasma") +
  ggtitle("Plasma") +
  theme_minimal()

p1 | p2

title: Visualization
text:
Exercice : cleaning”
Instruction : clean the starting graph.

Apply a minimalistic theme
Use viridis
Clarify the labels
Remove useless elements

. starting graph:

# Graph with several "problems"
p_to_improve <- mtcars %>%
  mutate(cyl = as.factor(cyl)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = cyl, y = mpg, fill = cyl)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(title = "Boxplot of MPG by Cylinder",
       x = "Cyl",
       y = "MPG") +
  theme_bw() + 
  theme(plot.background = element_rect(fill = "lightgray"))

p_to_improve









Possible correction


p_corrected <- mtcars %>%
  mutate(cyl = as.factor(cyl)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = cyl, y = mpg, fill = cyl)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_fill_viridis_d(begin = 0.3, end = 0.9) + # Palette discrète
  labs(title = "Distribution de la consommation de carburant",
       subtitle = "Selon le nombre de cylindres",
       x = "Nombre de cylindres",
       y = "Miles par gallon (US)",
       fill = "Cylindres") +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(legend.position = "top")

p_corrected

title: Visualization
text:
THM for part 1
. A good graph is above an effective graph.
. Best practices (colors, themes, labels) can be quickly mastered.
. ggplot2 gives us all the tools we need to apply them.

title: Visualization
text:
Enrichment and customization
Recap of best practices
. A basic, clean chart is the foundation from which to add advanced elements.
. Clear themes, accessible color palettes, and informative labels are essential.
Example: Chart enrichment
Aim: Enrich a basic chart with advanced visual elements (annotations, limits, etc.)
Instruction: Add the necessary elements to make this graph “publication-ready.”

title: Visualization
text:
Possible enriched graphs
. Annotations: Add annotations to guide the data interpretation.









. Fine customization : Add scales, legends and theme for a greater clarity.

title: Visualization
text:
Comparison & Discussion

Importantes Notes

Always check readability: Ensure that annotations do not obscure key information.
Use distinct but accessible colours.
Captions and titles should clearly convey the main message.

title: Great Tables
text:
Simulated example

set.seed(73)
dat.ex <- tibble(
  x = rnorm(100),
  f = gl(n = 2, k = 50, labels = c("A", "B")),
  y = -5*x + 10*as.numeric(f) + rnorm(100)
)

title: Great Tables
text:
Exercise level 1

Create your own toy dataset.
Use gt and/or gtsummary to create tables on your toy dataset.
Create a short R Markdown report with your data, a plot, and a beautiful table.

title: Great Tables
text:
Level Up!
Now, you are ready to include a Great Table in your R Markdown report on the COVID data.
